results.description:
The main shock caused damage to some 500 structures, primarily in five coastal municipalities, according to initial assessments. It also triggered power shutdowns across most of the island, which in turn shut down potable water pumps and treatment plants. These effects in turn drove about 5,000 residents to flee from their homes, due to potential damage, fear of the structural integrity of their homes and the potential effects of subsequent seismic activity. 

Following a series of smaller aftershocks during the week, a 5.9 magnitude quake on January 11th caused new damage and renewed public anxiety. Power and water service had been restored to some 97% of the island and there were no significant disruptions to the commercial supply chain. 

The US Geologic Service reports "it is likely that there will be smaller earthquakes over the next week, with 40 to 230 magnitude 3 or higher aftershocks. Magnitude 3 and above are large enough to be felt near the epicenter. The number of aftershocks will drop off over time, but a large aftershock can increase the numbers again, temporarily." 

The shock of this earthquake series-for an island still recovering from the catastrophic effects of hurricanes Irma and Maria-coupled with the public's uncertainty over when the current seismic activity will end and how much more damage it will cause has become the primary driver of unmet humanitarian need.
results.summary: United States - Puerto Rico: Earthquakes 01/20

actions_taken.summary: In coordination with State Governments and other emergency actors, the Australian Red Cross Emergency Services team (ARCES) have been responding to the bushfires since they first escalated in early November 2019. So far over 18,600 people have been supported by (ARCES), with over 1,590 staff and volunteers mobilised across multiple emergency operations centres and 105 evacuation and relief centres in affected areas. Their main activities have been community outreach, Psychosocial First Aid (PFA), food, water and hygiene items distribution, support to evacuation centres and services, emergency cash grants and their Restoring Family Links service “Register. Find. Reunite”. Medium and long-term recovery planning will commence in the coming weeks. Australian Red Cross are also monitoring smaller bushfires affecting the states of Tasmania (TAS) and Queensland (QLD), though they are not at a level that yet require emergency action.

results.description:
High temperatures and prolonged dry conditions have resulted in multiple bushfires in the states of New South Wales (NSW) and Australian Capital Territory (ACT) since early November 2019, and Victoria (VIC), Western Australia (WA) and South Australia (SA) since early December 2019. At least 23 people have died as a result of the bushfires, with six  people still missing in VIC and NSW. The bushfires continue to burn through a reported six million hectares across Australia, destroying bush and farmland, and multiple towns. An estimated 4,200 residential and public structures have been destroyed. Loss of wildlife is estimated in the millions, along with tens of thousands of livestock. Due to prevailing drought conditions over all affected states during 2019, agricultural and horticultural sectors will be impacted well into the long-term. Due to the changeable nature of this crisis, rapid assessments are ongoing and all reported figures are expected to change as the situation evolves.

In some locations, the scale and concentration of bushfires has created their own weather systems, generating pyrocumulonimbus clouds, trapping heat and generating strong wind and lightning strikes, in turn sparking further fires. High winds have also helped the bushfires to spread, with some fires ‘jumping’ over motorways and other major firebreaks. The pace at which the bushfires have spread and the smoke haze they have created has made it difficult for emergency services to access and evacuate some communities, at times forcing residents to relocate to beaches and other water bodies while they wait for rescue. Power, fuel and food supplies have been severely interrupted to some communities and road closures have been common. This has resulted in some communities being isolated, or only accessible by air (when smoke conditions allow). The bushfire and weather conditions have also severely impacted communications across most affected areas. The smoke haze has also significantly worsened air quality across South and East Australia, with some areas reaching 20 times above levels considered safe by the Australian Government. The reduction in air quality is a major public health concern and the Australian Ministry of Health is warning of significant long term health risks particularly for vulnerable members of the population such as elderly, infants and those already managing serious health conditions. Mental health is also a significant concern as people face the stress posed by living through bushfire events, the loss of friends and family, loss of livelihoods, property, pets and livestock, and for some, prolonged displacement. 

The NSW State Government has declared a state of emergency and the VIC State Government has declared a state of disaster, granting them each significant authority to mobilise additional resources and coordinate services and population movement in the emergency management of the bushfires. Current forecasts anticipate that the current bushfires will continue to burn at their current scale or higher, until at least March 2020. Though NSW and VIC have been the worst hit so far, extreme heat and drought conditions across Australia threatens a high likelihood of further bushfires in existing, and new areas over the coming months.
results.actions_others: The overall coordination of the bushfire response is managed by each state’s governmental disaster management department, the main actors being the State Fire Services, state police and relief agencies. The Australian Army, Navy and Air Force have also been mobilised to provide support. A significant number of wildlife rescue organisations are also part of the response. Australian Red Cross are working in coordination with all bushfire response actors.
results.summary: Australia Bushfires

event_details.name: Building collapsed in Kep Province, Cambodia, killed 36 peoples and 23 injured

results.description:
A seven-story under construction building collapsed on Friday, 03 January 2020, at around 16:30 in southern Kep province, Cambodia.The government are fully operating the search and rescue the injure, missing and death persons. The Prime Minister are at the ground and closely monitor and immediate assist the peoples with his technical team from all relevant sectors. At least 59 peoples were in the building just before it collapsed. The government officially announced and close the search and rescue operation by 11:35 am on Sunday 05 January 2020. The total number of deaths found is 36 (14 female; 2 children) and injured 23 ((8 female).    
The Kep provincial Red Cross Branch has been actively joint with the local authority to assist the victim and search/rescue team at the ground. 
The building was being constructed larger to seven-story while it was permitted for five-story high.
results.actions_others:
The UN; Australian Embassy; and China Embassy in Cambodia offers condolences to the families of the victims. 
the UN informed that UN system stands ready to work with the Royal Government of Cambodia and all partners to improve construction safety standards in the country.

results.description:
On 23 December 2019 at 5:00 AM a Tropical Cyclone, located East of Surigao Del Norte entered, the Philippine Area of Responsibility and named Tropical Storm “URSULA, international name PHANFONE. The tropical cyclone steadily intensifies into severe tropical storm at 2:00 AM 24 December, 2019 and at 11:00 AM of the same day, further intensifies into a typhoon prior to its landfall in Salcedo, Eastern Samar.
At 3:00 AM today, the eye of Typhoon "URSULA" was located, based on all the available data, at 335 km West of Subic, Zambales (14.5 °N, 117.2 °E ), with maximum sustained winds of 120 kph near the center and gustiness of up to 150 kph. Tail-end of Cold front affecting Northern Luzon.
The typhoon made seven (7) landfalls in Visayas and Southern Luzon provinces as follows; 
•	1st	24 December 2019; 4:45 PM	Salcedo, Eastern Samar
•	2nd	24 December 2019; 7:30 PM	Tacloban City, Leyte
•	3rd	24 December 2019: 9:15 PM	Cabucgayan, Biliran
•	4th	25 December 2019; 2:30 AM	Gigantes Island, Carles, Iloilo
•	5th	25 December 2019; 8:40 AM	Ibajay, Aklan
•	6th	25 December 2019; 1:00 PM	Caluya Island, Antique
•	7th	25 December 2019; 3:00 PM	Southern tip of Bulalacao, Oriental Mindoro

Typhoon "URSULA" is no longer directly affecting the country. However, the Tail-End of a Cold Front will bring moderate to occasional heavy rains over most of Cagayan Valley and Cordillera Administrative Region. This rainfall may trigger flooding and landslides in highly to very highly susceptible areas. For more information, refer to the Weather Advisory #1 on the Tail-End of a Cold Front issued at 11:00 AM today. Sea travel is risky, especially for small sea crafts, over the seaboards of Northern Luzon due to rough seas.
Typhoon Ursula exited the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) on 28 December 2019; 9:50AM.

 A total of 522,460 families/ 2,122,581 persons were affected in 2,544 barangays in Region V, VI, VII, VIII and CARAGA. Of which a total of 21,409 families or 84,909 persons are taking temporary shelter in 654 evacuation centers while 14,714 families/ 60,732 persons are served outside evacuation centers

A total of 147 cities/ municipalities experienced power outage in Regions of MIMAROPA, VI, VII. Of which, power in 31 cities/ municipalities were already restored.

A total of 153 cities/ municipalities experience power outage in Regions MIMAROPA, VI, VII, and VII. Of which, power in 38 cities/ municipalities were restored.

Damages and Casualties
-406,228  houses were damaged (301,759 partially ; 104,469 totally damaged)
-416 school facilities were reported partially damaged in different provinces of Region 4A, 4B, 5, 6 and 8.
-100 Public structures were damaged in MIMAROPA and VIII (75 partially damaged and 25 totally damaged). A totally of (3) three other structures were reported damage.
-30 Health Facilities were reported partially damaged in Regions MIMAROPA, VII, VIII.
-72 Roads sections and 4 bridges reported in Region 5, 6 and 8 were affected by TY URSULA. Of which 4 road section and 3 bridges are still not passable.
results.actions_others:
IV.	GOVERNMENT PREPAREDNESS AND RESPONSE
•	Facilitated the conduct of the Pre-disaster Risk Assessment (PDRA) Meeting and National Response Cluster Meeting on 26 December 2019.
•	PAGASA continues to provide updates through Severe Weather Bulletin
•	PAGASA has advised the public and the disaster risk reduction and management council concerned to monitor for the next update on this weather disturbance to be incorporated in the Public Weather Forecast.
•	All Quick Response Team Members and emergency equipment are on standby and ready for deployment. 
•	Local DRRMC’s conducted Pre-Disaster Risk Analysis (PDRA) meeting and activated respective EOC’s and raised alert levels
•	Conducted Pre-emptive and Force evacuation to high risk areas in different provinces of Visayas and Southern Luzon Provinces
•	PNP, BFP and other MDRRMC SAR teams are on standby
•	Coast guard and Philippine Ports Authority strictly implemented no sea travel to those areas with gale warning and provinces under Tropical Cyclone Warning Signal.
•	Department of Energy (DOE) through different agencies including NGCP conducted precautionary measures to minimize impact on transmission operations and facilities
•	DSWD Provincial, Regional and National Level relief assistance are on standby for distribution and augmentation.
•	Conducted clearing operations in major roads and highways

results.description:
On 23 December 2019 at 5:00 AM a Tropical Cyclone, located East of Surigao Del Norte entered, the Philippine Area of Responsibility and named Tropical Storm “URSULA, international name PHANFONE. The tropical cyclone steadily intensifies into severe tropical storm at 2:00 AM 24 December, 2019 and at 11:00 AM of the same day, further intensifies into a typhoon prior to its landfall in Salcedo, Eastern Samar.
At 3:00 AM today, the eye of Typhoon "URSULA" was located, based on all the available data, at 335 km West of Subic, Zambales (14.5 °N, 117.2 °E ), with maximum sustained winds of 120 kph near the center and gustiness of up to 150 kph. Tail-end  of Cold front affecting Northern Luzon.
The typhoon made seven (7) landfalls in Visayas and Southern Luzon provinces as follows; 
•	1st	24 December 2019; 4:45 PM	Salcedo, Eastern Samar
•	2nd	24 December 2019; 7:30 PM	Tacloban City, Leyte
•	3rd	24 December 2019: 9:15 PM	Cabucgayan, Biliran
•	4th	25 December 2019; 2:30 AM	Gigantes Island, Carles, Iloilo
•	5th	25 December 2019; 8:40 AM	Ibajay, Aklan
•	6th	25 December 2019; 1:00 PM	Caluya Island, Antique
•	7th	25 December 2019; 3:00 PM	Southern tip of Bulalacao, Oriental Mindoro
Typhoon "URSULA" is no longer directly affecting the country. However, the Tail-End of a Cold Front will bring moderate to occasional heavy rains over most of Cagayan Valley and Cordillera Administrative Region. This rainfall may trigger flooding and landslides in highly to very highly susceptible areas. For more information, refer to the Weather Advisory #1 on the Tail-End of a Cold Front issued at 11:00 AM today. Sea travel is risky, especially for small sea crafts, over the seaboards of Northern Luzon due to rough seas.
II.	SITUATION :

 A total of 44,792 families/ 185,168 persons were affected in 584 barangays in Region V, VI, VII, VIII and CARAGA. Of which a total of 12, 131 families or 43,850 persons are taking temporary shelter in 216 evacuation centers while 1, 218 families/ 5,578 persons are served outside evacuation centers

A total of 147 cities/ municipalities experienced power outage in Regions of MIMAROPA, VI, VII. Of which, power in 31 cities/ municipalities were already restored.

To this date of reporting, a total of 34 passengers were reported stranded still in Region VI due to the “Typhoon URSULA.”

results.description:
On 23 December 2019 at 5:00 AM a Tropical Cyclone, located East of Surigao Del Norte entered, the Philippine Area of Responsibility and named Tropical Storm “URSULA, international name PHANFONE. The tropical cyclone steadily intensifies into severe tropical storm at 2:00 AM 24  December, 2019 and at 11:00 AM of the same day, further intensifies into a typhoon prior to its landfall in Salcedo, Eastern Samar.
At 8:00 PM today, the eye of Typhoon "URSULA" was located, based on all the available data, at 75 km West Northwest of San Jose, Occidental Mindoro (12.6 °N, 120.4 °E ), with maximum sustained winds of 140 kph near the center and gustiness of up to 195 kph and moving West Northwest at 20 kph.
The typhoon made  seven (7) landfalls in Visayas and Southern Luzon provinces as follows; 
•	1st	24 December 2019; 4:45 PM	Salcedo, Eastern Samar
•	2nd	24 December 2019; 7:30 PM	Tacloban City, Leyte
•	3rd	24 December 2019: 9:15 PM	Cabucgayan, Biliran
•	4th	25 December 2019; 2:30 AM	Gigantes Island, Carles, Iloilo
•	5th	25 December 2019; 8:40 AM	Ibajay, Aklan
•	6th	25 December 2019; 1:00 PM	Caluya Island, Antique
•	7th	25 December 2019; 3:00 PM	Southern tip of Bulalacao, Oriental Mindoro
The Typhoon is expected to exit Philippine area of responsibility on Saturday afternoon  at west of Subic, Zambales. 

Lifelines:

Electricity	-	Electricity/ Power supply has been cut off since 24 of December 2019 starting in Samar-Leyte Provinces and In Northern Cebu, Bohol, Panay Island, Masbate and Mindoro Provinces as part of precautionary measure.
-	86 cities/municipalities experienced power outage of which 24 cities/municipalities (28%) were already restored  
-	Leyeco advised the community that the electricity will be resumed once supply from NGCP will be restored. Based also on direct call to the company, no major damage was reported except to the few street / village toppled electrical post due to winds and trees.
Water Supply	-	Water supply in all of the provinces monitored by the PRC are still functional and operational, except to those municipalities who relies on electricity for their water pump.
-	No reported damages on water system.
Communication	-	Smart and Globe Telecoms for SMS, Calls and Data were interrupted in most of the areas affected by the typhoons. Globe telecom has no to limited connection specifically in Samar-Leyte areas, Aklan, Capiz and Roxas due to the damages brought by the strong winds.
-	Aklan reported no signal both Smart and Globe
-	Internet connection area also limited in most of the provinces of Visayas ( Region VI, VII and VIII)

Displacements/Evacuation:
Based on the DSWD Report up to 88 evacuation centers were opened to cater 2,345 families or 8820 individuals for preemptive evacuation in provinces of MIMAROPA, Region V and Region VIII, of which 456 families are still in evacuation centers or displaced as of today ( 5pm, 25 December 2019 ).

results.description:
Los incendios Forestales comenzaron a las 15:45 de ayer martes 24 de Diciembre, en los sectores de Fundo La Plantación 2” y “Antena Microonda”, los cuales han consumido una superficie de 140 Hectáreas de pinos, pastizales y quebradas habitadas.
Según la información proporcionada hoy se ha dado inicio al catastro de familias en las zonas afectadas, sin embargo, por la complejidad de la zona y su acceso el fuego avanzo hasta las viviendas aledañas a esas quebradas, las cuales en su mayoría son de material ligero, y fueron consumidas en su totalidad en los sectores mencionados,
results.actions_others: A raíz de lo anterior, fueron habilitados 2 albergues: el Liceo Técnico de Mujeres de Valparaíso, en donde se está albergando a las familias afectadas por el incendio, y la Escuela Alemana  que está siendo utilizada como bodega para los enseres de las familias afectadas. Además, fueron gestionados por ONEMI, 800 frazadas, 400 colchones, 200 kit de higiene personal hombre y 88 kit de higiene personal mujer, el día de mañana jueves se enviarán nuevos kits de higiene mujer, para las personas afectadas. Asimismo, se habilitó un Puesto de Atención Médica para Animales de Compañía en la escuela Lorenzo Luzuriaga, ubicada en el cerro O’Higgins.

event_details.name: Sri Lanka - Heavy rain and landslide North-east monsoon

results.description:
Due to an active North-east monsoon conditions, Sri Lanka is experiencing heavy rains over the island since last few days. It is expected that the situation will enhance from tomorrow (22 Dec), particularly in Northern, Eastern, North-Central, Uva and Central provinces and in Hambantota district. 
The rainfall within the past 24 hours has exceeded 150mm, if the rain continues, people are advised to evacuate to a safe location to avoid the risk of landslides, slope failures, rock falls, cutting failures and ground subsidence. The National Building Research Organization (NBRO) has issued Level 3 (RED) alert to several DS Divisions in Matale, Kandy, Nuwara Eliya and Badulla districts.
As of 21 December, 26,492 people (7,565 families) have been affected (As per the Situation Report, Disaster Management Centre at 1800 hours). There have been three deaths reported and six people injured. Total of 47 housed reported fully damaged and 1,007 houses reported partially damaged. Total of 90 safety locations has been established in 9 districts with 11,916 people (3,314 families) evacuated. 
Sri Lanka Red Cross coordinates with the disaster management centre to respond when/if needed. In case of a response, Sri Lanka Red Cross district branches are on alert with its emergency stocks and Branch Disaster Response Teams (BDRT). At present SLRCS has deployed its BDRT teams in Anuradhapura and Badulla to conduct the initial assessment.
results.other_sources: Situation report (21  December 2019 at 1800hrs) - Disaster Manager Centre, Sri Lanka
results.summary: Sri Lanka - Heavy rain and landslide North-east monsoon

event_details.name: 6.9 MAGNITUDE EARTHQUAKE IN DAVAO DEL SUR

results.description:
A major earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 6.9 which tectonic in origin occurred in Padada, Davao del Sur on 2019 December 15 at 02:11 PM (Philippine Standard Time) located at 06.74 °N, 125.30 °E with depth of 003 km. No destructive tsunami threat exists based on available data 
but after shocks and damages are expected.

Reported Intensities are:
Intensity VII 	•	Matanao, Magsaysay, Bansalan & Hagonoy, Davao Del Sur; Digos City
Intensity VI	•	Padada, Sta. Maria, Sulop, Kiblawan & Malalag, Davao del Sur; Kidapawan City;
General Santos City; Malungon, Sarangani; Columbio, Sultan Kudarat
Intensity V 	•	Magpet & Arakan, Cotabato; Cotabato City; Tulunan & Matalam, North Cotabato; Davao City; Glan & Alabel, Sarangani; Tupi, South Cotabato
Intensity IV	•	Kadingilan, Damulog, Don Carlos, Pangantucan, Kitaotao, Kalilangan & Talakag,
Bukidnon; Isulan, Sultan Kudarat; Lake Sebu, South Cotabato
Intensity III	•	Dangcagan, Maramag, Bukidnon; Gingoog City; Cagayan De Oro City
Intensity II	•	Impasugong, Libona, Bukidnon; Dipolog City; Tubod, Lanao Del Norte; Butuan City
Intensity I 	•	Molave, Zamboanga Del Sur

The Mahayahay Bridge on Matina Pangi/Carlos P Garcia Road has been totally closed off to vehicles because of cracks found on its structure following the Magnitude 6.9 earthquake today. As of 15 December 2019; 4pm, all vehicles are diverted to Matina Crossing going to McArthur Highway. Davao City LGU is coordinating with DPWH on this matter. 

In General Santos City, classes are suspended in all levels, both public and private schools, colleges, and universities tomorrow, December 16, 2019 until further notice.
CDRRMO and other concerned government agencies will be conducting inspections of school buildings to assess their structural integrity.

The PRC Is monitoring the situation and damages thru our chapters:
Municipality of  Padada Davao del Sur
•	A 3 Storey Building in Padada Market, Davao Del Sur  reportedly collapsed, Ongoing rescue operation 
•	There were reported damaged in Water Reservoir and still for verification.
•	Police and Fire stations were reported partially damaged but still temporary restricted.
•	No  power and water supply in the municipality
•	 Initially reported with 24 individual Injured
•	There were street road reported with sustained damages (cracks) alternate routes are available to use.
Digos City, Davao Del Sur
•	Landslide reported  and access to Digos via Malungon is not accessible 
•	Fire reported in Phoenix Gasoline Station.
•	There were stores and banks in Digos City, Davao Del Sur reported with damages ( damaged ceiling, glass door etc.)
•	No electricity in Digos City
Municipality of   Matanao, Davao del Sur	•	Damages in Schools/Classrooms reported with sustained damages: (Kauswagan Elementary School, Langa-an Elementary School, Matanao National High School.
•	Established Evacuation Center at Matanao Elementary School and Brgy. Poblacion, estimated number of evacuees still for validation.
Municipality of   Magsaysay, Davao Del Sur	•	The municipal hall is reported partially damaged  (restricted temporarily)
•	Initially reported with 13 individual Injured
•	No recorded deaths related to the earthquake
•	Displacement reported in  Brgy. Glamang and for validation
North Cotobato	•	Landslide was reported at Umpan Village Brgy. Balabag Kidapawan City.
•	2 electrical posts totally collapsed in Brgy. Luna Municipality of Makilala
•	No injuries or dead reported in Kidapawan.

•	Deployed Davao City rescue team, General Santos and South Cotabato Ambulance Team  in Davao Del Sur.

results.description:
Suite au  passage du cyclone tropical Belna à Madagascar , la Croix rouge Malagsy a fait des activités post catastrophe et des activités de réponse visant à atteindre 500 familles dans la région de Boeny et Melaky. L'activité est réalisé grâce à un fonds d'urgence (DREF) alloué par la FICR.
3 équipiers de la FICR et de la PIROI ont été déployés en appui aux opérations de la société nationale.
Actuellement, des activités de réponses est en cours dans la région de Boeny par contre pour la région Melaky on attend les compléments des données venant de nos volontaires pour pouvoir évaluer et  faire une réponse . Notons que cette zone est  enclavée vu le problème d'accès nécessitant  plusieurs jours pour y arriver.
La Croix Rouge Malagasy ne cesse de collaborer avec les autorités locales pour la coordination et pour soutenir les victimes de ce cyclone.

results.description:
Se estima un aproximado 3.000.000 las personas afectadas directa e indirectamente a causa del estallido social. Si bien la cantidad de personas que se manifiestan a disminuido en relación con los primeros 30 días del comienzo del estallido social, las alteraciones orden público han ido en aumento a nivel nacional (Disturbios), donde las dinámicas sociales y económicas, se ven afectadas gravemente (principalmente al turismo y al comercio, a causa de las limitaciones en la comercialización como en el daño directo a los locales). Siendo las Regiones de Valparaíso, Biobío, Antofagasta, Araucanía y Metropolitana donde se registran las manifestaciones más masivas y con mayor nivel de incidentes violentos en estas últimas semanas.

En relación con las medidas del control del orden público y con la prohibición de uso de escopetas anti-disturbios (con munición no letal de balines/perdigones), El subsecretario del interior, Rodrigo Ubilla reveló que se evalúa la adquisición de LRAD, un dispositivo usado por la policía en Estados Unidos, que emite un sonido a gran volumen, más de 100 db y una alta frecuencia. Por lo que la adquisición de este dispositivo puede generar nuevas lesiones entre los manifestantes.

Por el momento, se mantienen las necesidades identificadas en las líneas de atención pre-hospitalaria (Primeros Auxilios y traslado sanitario) y Apoyo Psicosocial. Tal cual lo expresado, la sobrecarga de los Servicios Públicos de Emergencia y restricciones institucionales de los mismos relacionadas con la seguridad limitan su cobertura y alcance a todas las zonas y personas potencial o efectivamente lesionadas durante las manifestaciones masivas. Además, se percibe un aumento en la   percepción inseguridad de la población, por el incremento de la violencia en el desarrollo de manifestaciones y posterior a ellas, en referencia a bloqueos, barricadas, saqueos y enfrentamiento. Considerando que además los disturbios no solo se generan en los lugares donde se convocan las manifestaciones, si no también en las diferentes comunas a nivel nacional.
results.actions_others:
A nivel gubernamental se mantiene el contingente de fuerzas de orden y seguridad en la región metropolitana (Zona cero), al igual que en otras regiones con mayores actos de violencia como Araucanía, Biobío, Valparaíso y Antofagasta. Además de las acciones de restablecimiento del orden público, se continúan reforzando los dispositivos sanitarios en todas las regiones, principalmente a cargo del SAMU (Servicio de Atención Médica). 

Organizaciones de Derechos Humanos como INDH (Instituto Nacional de Derechos Humanos) siguen asumiendo el protagonismo en materia de observación, recepción de denuncias y abogacía.

Finalmente, y en varias Regiones, Organizaciones como Rescatistas Voluntarios y distintos grupos autoconvocados (Estudiantes, etc.) van institucionalizándose y consolidando sus servicios de asistencia sanitaria en las manifestaciones.
results.summary: Disturbios sociales Chile 12-12-2019

event_details.name: Adverse weather conditions heightening risk of flooding in Zimbabwe

results.description: The rain season has intensified, heightening the risk of localized flooding including other adverse damaging weather conditions such as hailstorms and violent thunderstorms. Since 08/12/19 rains have been unabated, pounding most districts in 6 provinces in the country namely Harare Metropolitan, Masvingo, Manicaland, Mashonaland East, Mashonaland West, Mashonaland Central.  The Meteorological Services Department has since issued watch alerts for flooding due to the heavy rainfalls received and expected to continue into the week ending 20/12/19.  Rainfall excesses of  200mm have been reported already in catchment areas for flood prone areas  such as Muzarabani and Gokwe. The continued rains poises risk of collapse of houses as the soils get saturated, and general flooding in low lying areas. ZRCS anticipates that the resulting emergency risks may affect 12,000 people (2000 households). These would need urgent humanitarian assistance as the rains  induced emergencies may  pose an additional threat to people already struggling with the food insecurity.
results.summary: Adverse weather conditions heightening risk of flooding in Zimbabwe

results.description:
La Croix-Rouge Malagasy a prepositionné une aide pour les quelques régions mpactées par le cyclone Belna, depuis lundi en fin d’après-midi. Ces kits deprépositionnement  sont destinés à subvenir à des besoins d’urgence en hygiène et abri. Deux camions remplis de bâches, de barres de savon, des ustensiles d’hygiène et de cuisine. Le stock de pré-positionnement d’Analamanga a donc été mobilisé et envoyé pour l’Ouest de Madagascar, zone d’impact et où l’on recense le plus de dégâts matériels et d’habitations endommagées. Les rafales de vent n’ont pas épargné les cases traditionnelles surtout dans le District de Soalala. 
Les volontaires de la Croix-Rouge Malagasy Boeny ont déjà entamé des activités évacuation des sinistrés, évaluation des dégât et appui le BNGRC dans la distribution des vivres. Ils ont aussi accompagné et renforcé la gestion des sites d’hébergement à Ambalavola. A Soalala, les activités volontaires sont encore au stade de l’évaluation des dégâts et au recensement de personnes sinistrées ainsi que des besoins primaires. Ces données permettront de définir les lignes stratégiques et d’identifier la suite des aides et leur distribution. 
Les volontaires formés dans ce cadre à travers différentes sessions de simulation sont déjà sur terrain mobilisables pour venir en appui aux branches locales. Ce sont des volontaires Spécialisés dans la Gestion des risques et catastrophes sont sur terrain (National Disaster Response Team et Branch Disaster Response Team). Notons qu’un centre opérationnel au siège de la Croix-Rouge Malagasy coordonne depuis trois jours la récolte des données sur la situation en temps réel. Il est aussi à la base de toute la stratégie de réponse fonctionnant par la remontée des informations des branches et des volontaires dans les localités touchées par Belna. Une cellule de veille informationnelle et médiatique est aussi sur pied pour recouper les données récoltées. 
La Croix-Rouge Malagasy continue ses activités jour et nuit en cette période cyclonique. Remplissant ses attributions d’auxiliaire des pouvoirs publics dans le domaine humanitaire, la Société nationale mobilise ses premières ressources via les volontaires et ceux spécialisés en situation de désastre. Les activités d’aide d’urgence permettent de supporter dans l’immédiat les besoins primaires de la population.

event_details.name: TY TISOY (KAMMURI) Operations Uodate as of 08 December 2019

results.description:
Typhoon "KAMMURI" has entered the Philippine area of responsibility and was named Typhoon “TISOY” at 1600H of 30 November 2019. On 05 December 2019, 8:00AM, Typhoon Tisoy exited the Philippine area of responsibility and weakened into a Tropical Depression. 
OTHER WEATHER DISTURBANCE 
As of 08 December 2019,  The effect of the tail end of cold front has weakened. However, Batanes, Cagayan including Babuyan Islands and Apayao will have cloudly skies with light to moderate rains due to the surge of Northeast Monsoon.
A total of 320, 006 families /1,397,330  persons were affected in 2,381 barangays in Region III, V, VIII, CAR, and CARAGA. Of which a total of 20, 574 families/ 90,582 persons are taking temporary shelter in 592 evacuation centers while 3, 623 families/ 15, 569 persons are served outside evacuation centers.
A total of 310 area in Region V, VII, CAR CALABARZON, NCR and MIMAROPA experienced power interruption. Of which, power in 31 areas were restored.

 A total of 17 transmission lines were reported affected by the weather disturbance in Luzon and Visayas.

As of 06 December 2019, 10:00 AM, transmission services in the affected provinces have been partially restored.
 Affected regions source of water are more on deep well-water pump that relies on electricity.  The reported limited power supply affect the water supply of the communities.
Currently, most of the area   communications are now being restored but still limited in different municipalities. During the height of the strong wind and for past few days communications are limited. And even the backed up radio system (specifically antenna) of different provinces were also damaged by the strong winds that limits sending information.
results.actions_others:
National DRRM Council (NDRRMC)
•	Activated the Response Cluster effective 03 December 2019, 08:00 AM
•	Deployed RDANA team to Region V on 05 December 2019.
•	Continuous monitoring and coordination for preparedness and proactive measures.
•	PAGASA continues to provide weather updates to concerned member agencies and local government unit.
•	Advised the public and the disaster risk reduction and management council concerned to monitor for the next update on this weather disturbance to be incorporated in the Public Weather Forecast.
•	NDRMM/ Local DRRMC conducted Pre-Disaster Risk Assessment (PDRA) meeting.
•	Prepositioned transport logistics assets for handling/ hauling of resources.
•	Continuous monitoring class suspensions and schools used as Evacuation Centers.

Regional DRRM Council (RDRRMCs)
•	RDRRMCs I, II, III, CALABARZON, MIMAROPA, V, VI, VII, VIII, CAR, NCR and CARAGA are continuously monitoring their areas of responsibility and are in coordination with their respective member agencies to ensure the widest dissemination of updates and advisories through SMS, facsimile and official media websites.
•	Reviewed/ revisited and developed respective contingency plan to serve as a tool in planning, assessing, responding, and resolving needs/ requirement for specific hazard/ emergency.
•	Conducted PDRA meetings.
results.summary: TY TISOY (KAMMURI) Operations Uodate as of 08 December 2019

event_details.name: Floods kill 11 in Bundibugyo District, Uganda

results.description:
Continued heavy rains in Uganda has caused serous flooding in Bundibugyo district in the Western part of the country when residents of Harugale and Bukonzo sub-counties this Saturday morning of 7th December 2019 woke up to find their houses, crops, sanitary facilities, critical infrastructures and other valuables submerged in floods waters.  So far 11 people are confirmed dead with many others still unaccounted for.  The foods destroyed access roads and  bridges which is limiting access of rescue workers to the affected communities
Relatedly, the heavy rainfall down also led to another floods event in Butaljea district that again occurred on 3rd/12/2019 as the results of River Manafwa bursting its banks, affecting Namulo, Tindi, Kanyenya, Kanghalaba and Doho sub-counties leaving a significant cross section of families displaced and abandoning their homesteads that are largely inhabitable. The water is increasingly beefing up, cutting off access connecting roads to Butaleja district. 97 households are currently displaced at a primary schools seek temporary shelter with other living with relatives in the raised neighboring villages of Nampologoma, Nabiganda and Lelesi Trading centres. Weather forecasts indicate the heavy rains will continue until end of December 2019, with resultant effects of floods, landslide and risk of disease outbreaks. 
This has since left over 12,000 residents of Butaleja District are living in dire conditions after floods washed away some of the houses and crops.
results.actions_others: The Uganda People's Defense Forces (UPDF) and Uganda Police are working with Red Cross volunteers supporting evacuation of families and the recovery of the dead bodies.
results.summary: Floods kill 11 in Bundibugyo District, Uganda

results.description:
On December 2, 2019, a cyclonic formation was born in the south eastern Indian Ocean.  As of December 5, 2019, this cyclonic depression is called Cyclone BELNA. The current trajectory threatens both of them from the Union of Comoros. This is the island of Anjouan, and the island of Mohéli. 
Given the negative impact of the passage of the previous Cyclone Kenneth, whose rescue operations are underway until May 2020. This new threat occurs while the population is still reeling from the preceding 
In remember, during the night of Wednesday 24th to Thursday 25th April 2019, Tropical Cyclone Kenneth went at its closest to the Comoros archipelago, mainly affecting the island of Grand Comoro (crossing the island) and causing subsequent flooding in Grande Comore, Moheli and Anjouan islands of Union of Comoros. 
Currently threatened populations are: Anjouan, 389445 peoples; Mohali: 50854 peoples.
The Government alerted populations to be vigilant.
The CRCo is preparing to respond to this imminent risk with public authorities in the event of an emergency. Hence  , CRCo project to DREF request to support the CRCo, to carry out preparedness activities (mobilization of volunteers’ teams, setting up emergency operations management structures, evaluation, coordination, pre-positioning of stock) and to have an on-site emergency response capacity to assist 200 households that would be affected in the immediate aftermath in the event of an impact of the cyclone on both islands).
The impact of the cyclone will determine the decision to revise the DREF, or to revise the Kenneth Appeal by integrating new needs or launch a separate Emergency Appeal.
The current CRCo response and early actions includes the following:  
•	Movement coordination meeting (IFRC, French Red Cross FRC, CRCo) every day at 15 h (local time)
•	Contingency plan active
•	Diffusion on the conduct of action in the event of a cyclone (Conduite à tenir en cas de cyclone)

•	Participation at the coordination meeting with COSEP, with support of the IFRC team in Comoros and of the French Red Cross delegation. 
•	Check on the availability of volunteers’ leaders (18 are available out of 25 in Ajouan and 16 out of 20 in Mohéli).  

•	Mobilization of 55 volunteers of which 30 will be focusing in the north of Anjouan and 25 in Moheli to provide early warning messaging preventively. The other 100 are on standby (50 Moheli and Anjouan and 50 volunteers in Grande Comores)
results.actions_others:
The Government has activated a cyclone alert on 05/12/2019. A sectoral coordination meeting was organised on 06/12/2019 at the Civil Protection Directorate
Several humanitarian actors are also active in the country, providing support to vulnerable populations. International humanitarian organizations present in Comoros include the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF), UNPD, WHO, WFP.

actions_taken.summary:
La Réponse du CRM
le Croissant-Rouge mauritanien a mis en place un cellule de veille au siège nationale ainsi que dans le comité local de Nouadhibou afin de collectées les information et  suivre l'évolution de la situation a NDB a fin d'établir des liens avec les autorités administratives et les membre du Mouvement présent au Mauritanie.
Le CRM a convoqué une réunion extraordinaire aujourd’hui avec le CRF, CICR dans le but d’harmonisé la coordination et d’étudier les actions possibles a faire s’il ya des besoins au profit des immigrants irréguliers en vue de soulager les souffrances des personnes affectées.
Une mission du CRM a été parti a Nouadhibou aujourd’hui pour faire état des lieux des besoins des immigrants et actualiser les données afin de communiquer un plan d’action détailles des besoins en étroite collaboration avec les autorités de Nouadhibou et les agences de nations unies notamment l’OIM

REUNION DE COORDINATION AVEC LE CRF ET LE CICR

event_details.name: Mauritanie, : Accident de naufrage d’un bateau transportant des immigrants irrégliers a Nouadhibou

results.description:
D’après les informations disponibles, des dizains migrants, pour la plupart originaires de Gambie et du Sénégal dont des femmes et des enfants, avaient cassé leur bateau dans les eaux internationales environ de 25 km au large de la ville de Nouadhibou, avant d'être retrouvés, où des dizaines de personnes sont mortes et d'autres portées disparues.
Les garde-côtes mauritaniens ont commencé à transférer les victimes d'un bateau chavirant dans les eaux mauritaniennes au large des plages de la ville de Nouadhibou, vers l'hôpital régional de la ville, où des dizaines d'immigrants illégaux ont été secourus, et la recherche de personnes disparues se poursuit à proximité du tragique accident.
Les opérations de recherche et de sauvetage toujours  en cours le vendredi 06 décembre 2019 la garde cote ont pu récupérer cinq nouveaux corps appartenant à des immigrants illégaux, selon l'agence de presse mauritanienne.
Un communiqué publié par le ministère de l'Intérieur et de la décentralisation mercredi soir (04 Déc 2019) qu'une patrouille des forces armées et des forces de sécurité chargées de sécuriser le terrain en terre a réussi à découvrir des survivants et des corps d'immigrants illégaux après que leur bateau a coulé sur les plages mauritaniennes en route vers l'Espagne.
Le communiqué indique que, selon des informations préliminaires obtenues le prémier jour auprès de certains des survivants, le bateau est parti de la capitale gambienne, Banjul transportant entre 150 à 180 personnes à bord, y compris des femmes, en particulier des jeunes hommes de 20 à 30 ans qui étaient sur le bateau.
Le communiqué souligne qu'après les opérations de recherche et de sauvetage, 85 survivants ont été retrouvés, car les autorités les ont hébergés selon "les principes de généreuse hospitalité requis par les principes de solidarité humaine, de fraternité et d'hospitalité africaine", selon le communiqué.

Tableau des données actualiser en date du 06 Déc 2019
Nombre total des immigrants estimés : 195 dont 172 gambien et 23 senegalais
Nombre de décès : 67 dont 62 Gambien et 05 Senegalais
Nombre de survivants : 85 dont 67 Gambien et 18 Senegalais
Nombre des personnes disparues : 41	cas declarrés sans identification---------	---------

FEMMES	                                                               ENFANTS MINEURS
Décées	03                                                   	Décées	---------
Vivants	02	                                                        Vivants	10
Disparus 08	                                                        Disparus	---------
TOTAL	13 Cas	                                                TOTAL	10 Cas

L'ambassadeur de Gambie en Mauritanie dans une déclaration qu'il a faite après une visite sur le lieu d’hébergement des migrants, a apprécié le niveau de gestion par les autorités mauritaniennes de l'incident de naufrage du bateau.
Il a souligné que ces procédures ont permis de sauver la vie de nombreux membres du groupe, de leur fournir les vivres et les couvertures nécessaires et de fournir les premiers soins médicaux dont ils avaient besoin, et ils ont été transférés dans un endroit approprié pour les héberger, tout en répondant à tous leurs besoins 
Le chargé d’affaire de l'ambassade du Sénégal a Nouakchott par intérim a salué le niveau de traitement par les autorités mauritaniennes de l'incident du naufrage du bateau qui transportait un groupe d'immigrants illégaux, dont des Sénégalais.
Par ailleurs, une unité des garde-côtes a arrêté une deuxième bateau dans les eaux territoriales au large du centre administratif d'Anwamgar relevant de la région de dakhlet Nouadhibou avec environ 140 personnes à bord tous des gambienne, que des sources officielles ont décrites comme des immigrants illégaux qui se dirigeaient vers les côtes européennes.

results.summary: Mauritanie, : Accident de naufrage d’un bateau transportant des immigrants irrégliers a Nouadhibou

contacts.name: Mbalo Thioune
contacts.title: Disaster Management Preparedness Officer and Surge Deployment Focal Point for Sahel Cluster

results.description:
Le Sénégal à l’image des autres pays du sahel souffre depuis plusieurs années d’un déficit pluviométrique. Ce qui a souvent impacté sur les moyens d’existence  des populations de certaines zones fortement vulnérables.
Cette année, le Sahel a été marqué par l’installation précoce de la saison agricole dans la bande côtière, les parties Centre et Est. Par contre la saison agricole a tardivement démarré dans la partie ouest du Sahel dont le Sénégal (cf. PREGEC 2019 et Bulletin pastoral ACF octobre 2019).
ACF sans son rapport Analyse de la biomasse 2019, montre que l’arrivée tardive des pluies sur le territoire Sénégalais a conduit à des niveaux de production de biomasse fortement en dessous de la moyenne pour la saison hivernale 2019.
Même si le niveau de satisfaction des besoins en eau des cultures et de la végétation a été satisfaisant dans l’ensemble du Sahel, il n’est pas le cas dans certains pays dont le Sénégal surtout au nord.
D'ailleurs d’importants déficits sont notés dans les régions de Louga, Matam, Saint-Louis, Kaolack, Tambacounda et Kaffrine. 
ACF montre également dans son rapport d’analyse que ces déficits, combinés à la situation pastorale précaire de 2018-2019, auront un impact négatif sur les activités pastorales. Ce qui permet d’enregistrer au Sénégal, des mouvements précoces de de troupeaux de la  Mauritanie vers le nord du Sénégal mais également du Nord vers le sud-est du Pays.
Le déficit pluviométrique est particulièrement noté dans 17 départements (Podor, Matam, Ranérou, Kanel, Kébémer, Linguère, Mbacké, Tivaouane, Gossas, Koungheul, Koupentoum, Kédougou, Médina Yoro Foulah, Goudomp, Bounkiling, Ziguinchor et Bignona). Ce déficit assez bien réparti dans le territoire national (au Nord, au Centre et au Sud) a installé une situation de vulnérabilité aussi bien sur les moyens d’existence que sur la consommation alimentaire (fiche de communication CH Sénégal Novembre 2019).
La zone agro-sylvopastorale où l'exploitation des ressources fourragères étant étroitement liée à la présence de points d'eau dispersés et de la disponibilité de pâturages, est souvent assujettie à des feux de brousse. Même s’il y’a une disponibilité des fourrage sur le plan national, celle-ci ne pourra pas couvrir  la demande fourragère pour toute période de soudure juin, juillet et Août 2019 ou précocement à partir du mois de Mars 2019.
Tous ces facteurs combinés peuvent impacter négativement sur la sécurité alimentaire et pastorale  des communautés vulnérables et éventuellement sur le moyens d’existence et occasionner des urgences humanitaires. . 
C’est dans ce cadre que cette alerte est lancée afin de permettre à la Croix-Rouge sénégalaise de monitorer au côté du Gouvernement du Sénégal l’évolution de la situation.
results.summary: Crise pastorale au Sénégal

actions_taken.summary: ZRCS provincial offices in affected areas have since flagged for support to respond to the emergencies with priorities rapid assessments.  NS response has been hamstrung by lack of resources; zero response financial resources and stocks (emergency shelter and NFIs). Most crisis modifier budgets in ongoing projects have been expended on Tropical Idai disaster earlier in March. As such Provincial staff and volunteers have managed minimal actions such as small scale rapid assessments. The ZRCS Manicaland office managed to distribute the remaining stock of  20 tarpaulins to affected families in Mutare. Currently ZRCS is planning resource mobilization with in-country PNSs. Priority target areas are the recently affected Matobo, Chiredzi and Bikita Districts. Priority response needs are [a] funds to cover rapid needs assessments and simultaneously distribute relief material to affected families,  [b] response stock acquisition to urgently cover 300HHs in Masvingo and Mat South. ZRCS urgently requires  emergency shelter (tarpaulins) and NFIs (blankets, utensils, buckets) to support the affected persons.

event_details.name: Zimbabwe_ Violent thunderstorms causes massive damages across the country _Dec 2019

results.description: Tuesday 12 November 2019, the Meteorological Services Department (MSD) issued an advisory alert of cloudy and warm to hot conditions with isolated thunderstorms expected in most parts of the country. By the 17th of November sporadic reports of adverse weather conditions (thunderstorms and windstorms wrecking damages in Kariba, Chinhoyi, Guruve, Muzarabani, Mutare, Chimanimani. . Lightning strikes claims 2 lives. About 36 HHs are affected. On the 9th of November, MSD issues a warning alert for adverse thunderstorms in Matabeleland South, Masvingo and southern areas of Midlands. On Friday 22 November, violent thunderstorms causes 1 death, 5 injuries & destroy 214 HHs in Bikita, 18 HHs in Chiredzi District (Masvingo Province). 	On 21st of November, similar storms damage 150 HHs in Matobo district (Mat. South Province), claims 4 lives and several injuries. Shelter assistance urgently required. The families are reportedly living in the open exposed to weather vagaries, or living with host families.
results.actions_others:
Civil Protection structures are carrying out joint rapid assessments; preliminary findings are awaited.
National Civil protection has requested support from the ZRCS and other INGOs. No confirmed support has been reported for Matobo, Bikita and Chiredzi.
IOM has done assessments in Mutare and Chimanimani violent windstorms emergencies and distributed urgent shelter and NFI support.
results.summary: Zimbabwe_ Violent thunderstorms causes massive damages across the country _Dec 2019

actions_taken.summary:
Bubulo Branch has deployed volunteers who are supporting  in the search and rescue of those entrapped in the flooding and landslides in Bududa, as well as provision of First Aid and referral of those injured. The Branch is conducting rapid needs assessment to ascertain magnitude and intensity of theses events and humanitarian needs of those affected.  
The National headquarters is working with Office of the Prime Minister and providing safety advisory for those traveling over rains and flooded areas.

IFRC country office in Uganda is providing technical support to the Uganda Red Cross to conduct needs assessment.  IFRC is considering allocating DREF to Uganda Red Cross to support provision of emergency shelter, WASH and health interventions to persons reported to have been affected in the previous floods events that occurred in November 2019

event_details.name: Six dead after a Landslide disaster in Bududa district, Uganda

results.description:
Torrential rains that started in October 2019 causing serous flooding and landslides that had so far affected over 15 districts in Uganda has continued with fresh event recorded today Tuesday 3rd December 2019.  Due to continuous rains that pounded Mt Elgon and many areas for the last 2 days,  that led to River Manafwa bursting its banks causing serous flooding and landslide. Today 3/12/2019, a new landslide event was experienced after tow-days heavy downpour that affected 3 villages in Bushika sub-county in Bududa district.  More serous flooding is being experienced in the downstream communities. In Bududa, the landslide so far affected 3 villages, destroying 15 houses.  By reporting time, 4 deaths have been reported (with one body of a male victim recovered this evening), with 4 persons reportedly missing. 3 Injured persons have been referred for treatment. The Budbulo Red Cross Branch search and rescue team is continuing to look for persons entrapped, as well as conducting more assessment to determine humanitarian needs of affected communities. Sironko Town Council and several villages were too flooded, leaving a lot of property destroyed.  
In a related events, the heavy rains have caused River Nile to burst its banks causing massive flooding that cut off the road network along the Karuma-Arua highways at Pakwach bridge this evening. The floods water swept away along the River Nile stream a lorry that was attempting to cross the flooded river on Pakwach bridge. This has caused heavy traffic with many travelers stranded as the road network is currently diverted a very long way to Wanseko Ferry in Buliisa district or Gulu-Adjumani through Laropi ferry.  Also, Uganda National Roads Authority (UNRA) today reported closure of  Humura-Kanungu road section that connects Kanungu to Rubanda district as most parts of the road section have been destroyed by flooding. Weather reports indicate that this situation is expected to continue till end of December 2019.
results.actions_others: Office of the Prime Minister (OPM) in the Ministry of Disaster Preparedness, Relief and Refugee affairs is working with the Uganda Police Force to support evacuation and traffic management in the affected highways.  Respective District Disaster Management  Committees (DDMCs) have been activated to coordinate rescue efforts. On 27th November 2019, Government of Uganda launched an appeal  of supplementary budget worth Uganda Shs. 43 billion (equivalent to USD 11,513,700 ) for floods-related emergency.
results.summary: Uganda Floods & landslides continue to wreck havoc

actions_taken.summary: at the moment SLRCS monitoring situation and our branch response teams on alert.

countries_details.society_name: The Sri Lanka Red Cross Society
countries_details.name: Sri Lanka

event_details.name: Heavy Rain and landslide North East Monsoon - Sri Lanka

results.description:
Heavy rains in East, North, North Central, Sabaragamuwa, Uva and Westen provinces have resulted in localized floods, high winds and landslides in nine districts since the early afternoon of 30 November 2019. Some areas have received an average rainfall as high as 200mm; the highest rainfall (243mm) was recorded in Kalutara district, followed by Kurunegala (188mm), Anuradhapura (172mm), Kandy (124mm). In several other areas, heavy rains were reported. 
Major reservoirs in Hambantota, Mannar, Kurunegala, Puttalam, Anuradhapura and Kilinochchi Districts are presently spilling. There are minor localized floods reported in most of the above-mentioned locations, and if Anuraadhapara, Battociloa, Hambanthota, Mannar and Kurunegala districts continue to receive heavy rainfall, moderate floods can be expected.  
As of 2 December, 14,164 people (4,153 families) have been affected (As per the Situation Report, Disaster Management Centre at 1800 hours). There have been five deaths reported with a further five people injured and one person reported missing.
259 houses have been reported partially damaged, 6 houses had been fully destroyed. Total of 29 safety locations has been established in 7 districts with 3,149 people (946 families) evacuated.
Sri Lanka Red Cross coordinates with the disaster management centre to respond when/if needed. In case of a response, Sri Lanka Red Cross district branches are on alert with its emergency stocks and Branch Disaster Response Teams.
results.actions_others: Coordination stakeholder meetings
results.summary: Heavy Rain and landslide North East Monsoon - Sri Lanka

actions_taken.summary:
The Philippine Red Cross (PRC) National Headquarters Office (NHQ) and its Chapters in the areas of Bicol Region, Southern Luzon, National Capital Region and Central Luzon are on standby and are on monitoring for the possible major impacts of Typhoon Tisoy. 
National Headquarters
•	Activated Emergency Operation Center for Typhoon Tisoy and continuously monitoring the weather, situations and providing pertinent information to offices and chapter. 
•	Conducted Pre-Disaster Meeting last 29 November 2019 in the OpCen.
•	Services and offices activated their staff and volunteers to support the operation. And updated the list of manpower and assets that can be mobilized or deployed.
•	DMS requested for activation of PRC Emergency relief fund and imminent DREF to IFRC to support the preparedness activities of PRC. 
•	As part of initial preparedness initial assets and resources were deployed to be stationed in Legaspi Albay such as 1 Unit of Tractor Head with 40 footer Container Van ( currently in Legaspi)  and 1,500 sets of Non Food Items  ( Sleeping Kit, Hygiene Kit, Jerry Can  and Tarpaulin and currently located in Allen Northern Samar). Relief Items will support priority affected provinces. 
•	Conducted briefing with the RCRC partners
•	Cash advances were released to NHQ offices for emergency deployment and Humanitarian Response
•	NHQ deployed its humanitarian response, composed of emergency assets and manpower of the different services to support Southern Luzon and Bicol Region. Transitory base  will be at Quezon Lucena and will be deployed to the areas where the situation calls for these resources.
•	Regional Warehouses particularly in Subic, Batangas and Mandaluyong warehouse are already activated and will be on standby for possible augmentation to NCR, Central Luzon and Southern Luzon areas.
•	DMS through the Forecast based Financing Project under the support of the German Red Cross tested Early action plan in Camarines Norte and Catanduanes. This will include the early harvesting of crops, evacuation of livestock and strengthening the shelters for up to 15 priority barangays. 
Chapters
•	Chapters under Tropical Cyclone Warning Signals (TCWS) were advised to be on alert and standby for monitoring and to report any untoward incidents.
•	PRC Chapters coordinated with the Local DRRMC’s, for Pre-Disaster Risk Analysis (PDRA) and response cluster activation.
•	Response Teams such as RC143 and RCAT 143 are alerted for local response, including the Emergency Response Unit for Water Search and Rescue and Ambulance Medical Team, Hot meals/Ready to eat food provision are on standby for augmentation;
•	Submitted chapter preparedness checklist to NHQ by 15 chapters;
•	Activated chapter Communication Centers for submission of situational reports/ updates 
•	Identified areas high risk of flooding, storm surge and strong winds and reported to NHQ
•	PRC local chapters prepared and supported pre-emptive evacuation, provision of first aid management, transport, welfare assistance and provision of hot meals as needed;
•	Cash Advances has been released to ten (10) chapters namely, Quezon Lucena, Camarines Norte, Camarines Sur, Sorsogon, Catanduanes, Mindoro Occidental, Romblon, Marinduque, Eastern Samar, Negros Oriental
•	Implemented the Forecast based financing through provision of evacuation kit for livestock, provision of shelter strengthening kit and assisting farmers to pre harvest through cash for work in Catanduanes and Camarines Norte.
Imminent DREF amounting to CHF 47,188 or  Php 2,450,000  has been approved  by the  IFRC to support PRC Operational Cost for Preparedness Actions.

results.description:
Typhoon "KAMMURI" has entered the Philippine area of responsibility and was named Typhoon “TISOY” at 1600H of 30 November 2019. The center of the Typhoon was located based on al available data at 1,165 km East, East of Virac Catanduanes (13.4 °N, 135.0 °E), moving West Southwest at 15 km/h with a maximum sustained winds up to 150 km/h near the center and gustiness of up to 185 km/h. 
As of 7:00pm today, the eye Typhoon “Tisoy” further intensifies and is about to make landfall over Sorsogon. The eyewall of the typhoon is now bringing violent winds over Northern Samar, Catanduanes, Camarines Sur and Sorgosogon. At 7:00 PM today, the eye of Typhoon “TISOY” was located based on all available data including Virac Doppler Radar at 90km East of Junan, Sorosgon (12.9 °N, 124.8 °E) with the maximum sustained winds of 165 kph near the center and gustiness of up to 230 kph moving west at 15 kph. 
Possible Storm Surge height in surge prone areas: more than 3.0 meters over several coastal areas in Catanduanes, Camarines Norte, and Camarines Sur; up to 3 meters over several coastal areas in Batangas, Quezon, Albay, and Marinduque. For more information, refer to Storm Surge Warning #5 issued at 8 PM today. 
The eyewall of the typhoon is now bringing violent winds over Northern Samar, Catanduanes, Albay, Camarines Sur and Sorsogon. Between tonight and tomorrow, frequent to continuous heavy to intense rains over Bicol region, Northern Samar, Southern Quezon, Marinduque and Romblon. Frequent to continuous rains over Samar, Eastern Samar, Rizal, rest of Quezon, Laguna, Oriental Mindoro. Moderate to intermittent heavy rains over Metro Manila, Occidental Mindoro, rest of CALABARZON, Cagayan, Isabela, Aurora and the rest of Eastern Visayas.
Sea travel is risky over the seaboard of areas under Tropical Cyclone Warning Signal (TCWS), the seaboards of Northern Luzon, the western seaboard of Palawan, central seaboard of Visayas, and the northern Seaboard of Mindanao due to prevailing or forecast rough sea conditions which maybe perilous for maritime activities especially for those using small seacrafts.
People living near the low lying coastal areas of the above mentioned provinces and the Local Disaster Risk reduction and Management Councils (LDRRMCs) concerned are advised to take the necessary precautionary measures.

OTHER WEATHER DISTURBANCE

Gusty conditions may also be experienced in areas in Northern Luzon that are not under TCWS (especially in the coastal and mountainous zones) due to the Northeast Monsoon.
results.actions_others:
GOVERNMENT PREPAREDNESS AND RESPONSE 

•	PAGASA continues to provide updates through Severe Weather Bulletin
•	PAGASA has advised the public and the disaster risk reduction and management council concerned to monitor for the next update on this weather disturbance to be incorporated in the Public Weather Forecast at 4 PM today and 4 AM tomorrow.
•	Local DRRMC’s conducted Pre-Disaster Risk Analysis (PDRA) meeting.
•	Conducted Pre-emptive and Force evacuation to high risk areas in Bicol and Samar Provinces.
results.summary: TYPHOON TISOY (KAMMURI) Operations Update

actions_taken.summary: Les volontaires ont ete deployé pour les actions de premiers secours, evacuation des blesses et des eaux pluviales. La CRT a distibuée des tarpaulin et des jerrycan pour 100 ménages dans la localité de ATI dans la province Batah.

results.description: Année 2019 comme les années passées, certaines provinces du Tchad est encore soumises à de fortes pluies ayant occasionné des inondations. Plusieurs localités à travers le pays sont affectées  à des degrés différents causant par endroit  d’importants dégâts matériels touchant les concessions, les biens divers (animaux, vivres, autres) et des pertes en vies humaines. Le sinistre a engendré une situation humanitaire désastreuse dans toutes les localités touchées. Conformément à sa mission humanitaire, la Croix- Rouge du Tchad envisage à travers ses partenaires d’assister les populations éprouvées. Elle sait compter en cela sur la mobilisation de toutes les composantes du mouvement Croix- Rouge / Croissant Rouge (CICR, FICR, SNPs) autour de l’idéal humanitaire.
results.summary: Tchad - Cluster du Sahel

actions_taken.summary:
The Philippine Red Cross (PRC) National Headquarters Office (NHQ) and its Chapters in the areas of Bicol Region, Southern Luzon, National Capital Region and Central Luzon are on standby and are on monitoring for the possible major impacts of the Tropical Cyclone Tisoy (Kammuri).

actions_taken.summary:
A recent report received from MRCS Kelantan indicated that MRCS Flood Operations Centre has been established at the State branch office in Kota Bharu since 0800 a.m. on 1 Dec.2019 to help coordinate and assist flood relief and response efforts to communities affected by the floods in Kelantan. Some 60 temporary relief centres have been opened to house some 6,013 people affected by the floods.

MRCS Kelantan has deployed a total of 40 Red Crescent volunteers and staff in the following areas to support the relief operations in Pasir Mas and Kuala Krai areas. 10 volunteers are on duty helping out at the temporary relief centre in Sungai Embak, Kuala Krai, while another 10 VAD (voluntary aid detachment) unit volunteers are supporting relief activities at the temporary relief centre at Sek. Menengah Keb. Agama (SMKA) Lati in Pasir Mas. 10 volunteers support SK Bunohan, Tumpat, Kelantan and others 10 standby at MRC State headquarters for supporting on logistics.

results.description: After a week of heavy rains in several parts of Kuala Krai, Kelantan and Besut, Terengganu, it has affected several communities.  The meteorology department has issued multiple warnings regarding strong winds and rough seas (category 2) on November 30, 2019. As of December 1, 2019, some 89 temporary evacuation centres have been activated to cope with the displaced population and the numbers are rising.  The government's Emergency Operation Centre (EOC) is actively monitoring and coordinating the situation. MRCS is also liaising with the authorities through its branches to provide support whenever needed.
